samples.context: Many fully differentiated organisms have the ability to give rise to new individual organisms from their body parts. For example, simple animals like Hydra and Planaria can be cut into any number of pieces and each piece grows into a complete organism.
samples.question: What is an example of an organism capable of regeneration?

samples.context: Regeneration is carried out by specialised cells. These cells proliferate and make large numbers of cells. From this mass of cells, different cells undergo changes to become various cell types and tissues.
samples.question: What role do specialised cells play in regeneration?

samples.context: Regeneration is not the same as reproduction, since most organisms would not normally depend on being cut up to reproduce. Organisms such as Hydra use regenerative cells for reproduction in the process of budding.
samples.question: How is regeneration different from reproduction?

samples.context: In Hydra, a bud develops as an outgrowth due to repeated cell division at one specific site. These buds develop into tiny individuals and when fully mature, detach from the parent body and become new independent individuals.
samples.question: What process do Hydra use for reproduction?

samples.context: From this mass of cells, different cells undergo changes to become various cell types and tissues. These changes take place in an organised sequence referred to as development.
samples.question: What is the organized sequence of cell changes called?
